results.title: First aid: everyday emergencies
results.brief_description: Describes treatment for snakebite; poison taken internally; poison ivy, oak and sumac; chemical in the eye; soft and hard foreign matter in the eye; foreign object in the nose; bug or insect in the ear; something stuck in the throat; splinters; blisters; faintness; artificial respiration, back-pressure armlift method; carbon monoxide poisoning and electric shock.

results.title: First aid
results.brief_description: A film of historic interest: an official training film produced for the War department in three parts. Part 1: emergency treatment of bleeding wounds, including self-administration. Covers the arterial system, pressure points and application of tournequets. Part 2: emergency treatment of broken bones. Part 3: covers methods of removing the wounded.

results.title: First aid action
results.brief_description: Concentrates upon basic first aid steps. Simulated situations provide an opportunity to discuss and demonstrate mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, shock, bleeding, burns, fractures, poisoning and sudden illness. A recap is made of all first aid directions. Shots of real accidents provide realism which reinforce the film’s theme. Narrated by Burt Reynolds.

results.title: Fires were started
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Jennings, Stewart McAllister, Ian Dalrymple and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: A main contribution of Britain to the development of cinematography has been the creation of a distinctive school of film-making - the documentary film. Using non-professional actors “FIRES WERE STARTED” is the first feature film by Humphrey Jennings and is one of the most moving of the war documentaries, recapturing the typical atmosphere of the war on Britain’s civilian front. The film is a tribute to the work of the Auxiliary Fire Service, described through the events of one-day activities. The story unfolds without effort from the early morning assembly of crew at the fire station, through the routine of the day, to the fighting of a blazing warehouse at night.

results.title: Fireline
results.creator_credit: Rodney Musch, Norman Laird and Tasmania. Dept. of Film Production
results.brief_description: Shows methods and uses of making a fireline - a line made or used to stop the spread of a bushfire. The fire is contained with a strip either man-made or mechanically made. Defines fire-edge and fire-head, and then demonstrates two techniques of fire fighting: parallel attack and direct attack. Suggests methods of controlling fire crews and recommends safe clothing.

results.title: Fire without smoke
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information and Dept of Scientific and Industrial Research
results.brief_description: Traces the development of a simple but effective device for abolishing the industrial smoke menace. In wartime the black smoke trails from ships’ funnels indicated the position of convoys. Experiments carried out on board ship and at the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research’s Fuel Resesarch Station resulted in a new boiler door fitment which minimised the danger. Redesigned to suit industrial boilers, the smoke eliminator door also saves a considerable quantity of fuel.

results.title: Fire vs fire
results.brief_description: A fire control training film, based on a conference held to discuss burning out and backfiring as techniques of controlling forest fires. The indirect attack is backfiring (backburning) toward the main fire from a distance. Burning out necessitates working in close and burning toward the fire.

results.title: Fire: two ways out
results.brief_description: Homes can burn very rapidly. Victims generally suffocate and become unconscious before the fire actually reaches them. It is important to know how to escape if a fire threatens your home. Two escape routes must be planned in advance in case one is blocked by flames.

results.title: Fire risks with underground conveyors
results.creator_credit: Grahame Tharp, Jack Chambers, Data Film Productions and National Coal Board
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how fires are caused on mine conveyor belts, how correct pit maintenance can prevent many of these outbreaks and how National Coal Board research is developing devices and materials to reduce these risks. Reference is made in the film to the use of polyvinyl chloride plastic for conveyor belts.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Grahame Tharp, Jack Chambers, Data Film Productions and National Coal Board

results.title: Fire: not in my house
results.brief_description: The aim of the film is to motivate the viewer to clean up fire hazards in their home. Home fires can be more immediately damaging than ecological pollution. Several people are spectators at a home fire; on their return home, they recognise fire hazards in their own environment, and quickly take steps to eliminate the possibility of fires in their homes.
